content: "http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/05/31/AR2009053101181.html?wprss=rss_politics" quote: George R. Tiller, the nation's most prominent provider of controversial late-term abortions, was shot and killed yesterday in the lobby of his Lutheran church in Wichita, where he was serving as an usher. "http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2009/05/31/tiller/index.html" quote: When his show airs tomorrow, Bill O'Reilly will most certainly decry the death of Kansas doctor George Tiller, who was killed Sunday while attending church services with his wife. Tiller, O'Reilly will say, was a man who was guilty of barbaric acts, but a civilized society does not resort to lawless murder, even against its worst members. And O'Reilly, we can assume, will genuinely mean this. But there's no other person who bears as much responsibility for the characterization of Tiller as a savage on the loose, killing babies willy-nilly thanks to the collusion of would-be sophisticated cultural elites, a bought-and-paid-for governor and scofflaw secular journalists. Tiller's name first appeared on "The Factor" on Feb. 25, 2005. Since then, O'Reilly and his guest hosts have brought up the doctor on 28 more episodes, including as recently as April 27 of this year. Almost invariably, Tiller is described as "Tiller the Baby Killer." Tiller, O'Reilly likes to say, "destroys fetuses for just about any reason right up until the birth date for $5,000." He's guilty of "Nazi stuff," said O'Reilly on June 8, 2005; a moral equivalent to NAMBLA and al-Qaida, he suggested on March 15, 2006. "This is the kind of stuff happened in Mao's China, Hitler's Germany, Stalin's Soviet Union," said O'Reilly on Nov. 9, 2006. O'Reilly has also frequently linked Tiller to his longtime obsession, child molestation and rape. Because a young teenager who received an abortion from Tiller could, by definition, have been a victim of statutory rape, O'Reilly frequently suggested that the clinic was covering up for child rapists (rather than teenage boyfriends) by refusing to release records on the abortions performed. When Kansas Attorney General Phill Kline, an O'Reilly favorite who faced harsh criticism for seeking Tiller's records, was facing electoral defeat by challenger Paul Morrison, O'Reilly said, "Now we don't endorse candidates here, but obviously, that would be a colossal mistake. Society must afford some protection for viable babies and children who are raped." (Morrison ultimately unseated Kline.) This is where O'Reilly's campaign against George Tiller becomes dangerous. While he never advocated anything violent or illegal, the Fox bully repeatedly portrayed the doctor as a murderer on the loose, allowed to do whatever he wanted by corrupt and decadent authorities. "Also, it looks like Dr. Tiller, who some call Tiller the Baby Killer, is spending a large amount of money in order to get Mr. Morrison elected. That opens up all kinds of questions," said O'Reilly on Nov. 6, 2006, in one of many suggestions that Tiller was improperly influencing the election. Tiller's excuses for performing late-term abortions, O'Reilly suggested, were frou-frou, New Age, false ailments: The woman might have a headache or anxiety, or have been dumped by her boyfriend. She might be "depressed," scoffed O'Reilly, which he dismissed as "feeling a bit blue and carrying a certified check." There was, he proposed on Jan. 5, 2007, a kind of elite conspiracy of silence on Tiller. "Yes, OK, but we know about the press. But it becomes a much more intense problem when you have a judge, confronted with evidence of criminal wrongdoing, who throws it out on some technicality because he wants to be liked at the country club. Then it's intense." Tiller, said O'Reilly on Jan. 6 of this year, was a major supporter of then-Gov. Kathleen Sebelius. "I think it's unfairly characterized as just a grip and grin relationship. He was a pretty big supporter of hers." She had cashed her campaign check from Tiller, "doesn't seem to be real upset about this guy operating a death mill, which is exactly what it is in her state, does she?" he asked on July 14 of last year. "Maybe she'll - maybe she'll pardon him," he scoffed two months ago. This is where it gets most troubling. O'Reilly's language describing Tiller, and accusing the state and its elites of complicity in his actions, could become extremely vivid. On June 12, 2007, he said, "Yes, I think we all know what this is. And if the state of Kansas doesn't stop this man, then anybody who prevents that from happening has blood on their hands as the governor does right now, Governor Sebelius." Three days later, he added, "No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands. But now so does Governor Sebelius. She is not fit to serve. Nor is any Kansas politician who supports Tiller's business of destruction. I wouldn't want to be these people if there is a Judgment Day. I just - you know...Kansas is a great state, but this is a disgrace upon everyone who lives in Kansas. Is it not?" This characterization of Tiller fits exactly into ancient conservative, paranoid stories: a decadent, permissive and callous elite tolerates moral monstrosities that every common-sense citizen just knows to be awful. Conspiring against our folk wisdom, O'Reilly says, the sophisticates have shielded Tiller from the appropriate, legal consequences for his deeds. It's left to "judgment day" to give him what's coming. O'Reilly didn't tell anyone to do anything violent, but he did put Tiller in the public eye, and help make him the focus of a movement with a history of violence against exactly these kinds of targets (including Tiller himself, who had already been shot). In those circumstances, flinging around words like "blood on their hands," "pardon," "country club" and "judgment day" was sensationally irresponsible. Has O'Reilly been, in effect, yelling "Fire" in a crowded theater and therefore, does he have some responsibility for inciting the death of Doctor Tiller, who was murdered standing in the foyer of his church during Sunday religious services, by an anti-abortion terrorist? Or was it just the act of a terrorist, and O'Reilly's continual attacks on the doctor ("No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands") had no connection with his murder?

content: Just to correct something here... The vast majority of late-term abortions do not occur because the child isn't wanted. Typically, they occur because of a severe deformity in the fetus or a major health problem for the mother. I used to be obsessively pro-life, and I heard all the rhetoric about late-term abortions, and I thought it was that simple. I THOUGHT that they happened because women who were stupid and waited to get the abortion (which I thought was wrong anyway), and that healthy infants were being slaughtered. And THAT sort of lie is the garbage I believed because I swallowed the right-wing religious rhetoric hook, line, and sinker. The truth is that late-term abortions only occur in extreme circumstances. Often, the babies are WANTED, and it turns out that the baby would be born with such extreme deformities (malfunctioning organs, missing heart chambers, NO BRAIN) that it would only suffer severely before dying a miserable death. Sometimes, the risk is even so bad that the fetus could die while still in the mother, leading to severe complications that put the mother's life at risk. These things HAPPEN. And there's often no way to know until LATE in the pregnancy. Go on... read a few case studies. Read it, if you dare to subject yourself to the medical truths. Other circumstances are when younger girls are raped and are not allowed to see a doctor until it becomes obvious that there's no way to hide the pregnancy. This image of perfectly healthy mothers with perfectly healthy fetuses strolling in for late-term abortions because they just decided they had a "headache" (as one poster here put it), or were depressed, or just decided they didn't want a kid... that's BULL. You see, it's easy to condemn things when you have an idealized negative view of the opponents. It's easy to condemn women and the doctors who provide the services they need when you don't know the specifics, when you can imagine that they're callous, careless people who want to kill children... which is the farthest thing from the truth.

content: O'Reilly repeatedly claimed that Dr. Tiller, or "Tiller the Killer" as he referred to him, would perform late term abortions right up to the end of the ninth month for anyone with $5,000, no questions asked. He claimed you could "murder your child" simply because you were having a bad day. That's typical O'Reilly and FOX Noise BS! A late term abortion can't legally be performed in Kansas until after at least two physicians have independently determined that not terminating the pregnancy would cause serious irreparable harm to the mother. In some cases that would include the mother's probable death. I can't imagine any pregnant woman or doctor taking such a decision lightly.

content: "http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/05/31/AR2009053101181.html?wprss=rss_politics" quote: George R. Tiller, the nation's most prominent provider of controversial late-term abortions, was shot and killed yesterday in the lobby of his Lutheran church in Wichita, where he was serving as an usher. "http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2009/05/31/tiller/index.html" quote: When his show airs tomorrow, Bill O'Reilly will most certainly decry the death of Kansas doctor George Tiller, who was killed Sunday while attending church services with his wife. Tiller, O'Reilly will say, was a man who was guilty of barbaric acts, but a civilized society does not resort to lawless murder, even against its worst members. And O'Reilly, we can assume, will genuinely mean this. But there's no other person who bears as much responsibility for the characterization of Tiller as a savage on the loose, killing babies willy-nilly thanks to the collusion of would-be sophisticated cultural elites, a bought-and-paid-for governor and scofflaw secular journalists. Tiller's name first appeared on "The Factor" on Feb. 25, 2005. Since then, O'Reilly and his guest hosts have brought up the doctor on 28 more episodes, including as recently as April 27 of this year. Almost invariably, Tiller is described as "Tiller the Baby Killer." Tiller, O'Reilly likes to say, "destroys fetuses for just about any reason right up until the birth date for $5,000." He's guilty of "Nazi stuff," said O'Reilly on June 8, 2005; a moral equivalent to NAMBLA and al-Qaida, he suggested on March 15, 2006. "This is the kind of stuff happened in Mao's China, Hitler's Germany, Stalin's Soviet Union," said O'Reilly on Nov. 9, 2006. O'Reilly has also frequently linked Tiller to his longtime obsession, child molestation and rape. Because a young teenager who received an abortion from Tiller could, by definition, have been a victim of statutory rape, O'Reilly frequently suggested that the clinic was covering up for child rapists (rather than teenage boyfriends) by refusing to release records on the abortions performed. When Kansas Attorney General Phill Kline, an O'Reilly favorite who faced harsh criticism for seeking Tiller's records, was facing electoral defeat by challenger Paul Morrison, O'Reilly said, "Now we don't endorse candidates here, but obviously, that would be a colossal mistake. Society must afford some protection for viable babies and children who are raped." (Morrison ultimately unseated Kline.) This is where O'Reilly's campaign against George Tiller becomes dangerous. While he never advocated anything violent or illegal, the Fox bully repeatedly portrayed the doctor as a murderer on the loose, allowed to do whatever he wanted by corrupt and decadent authorities. "Also, it looks like Dr. Tiller, who some call Tiller the Baby Killer, is spending a large amount of money in order to get Mr. Morrison elected. That opens up all kinds of questions," said O'Reilly on Nov. 6, 2006, in one of many suggestions that Tiller was improperly influencing the election. Tiller's excuses for performing late-term abortions, O'Reilly suggested, were frou-frou, New Age, false ailments: The woman might have a headache or anxiety, or have been dumped by her boyfriend. She might be "depressed," scoffed O'Reilly, which he dismissed as "feeling a bit blue and carrying a certified check." There was, he proposed on Jan. 5, 2007, a kind of elite conspiracy of silence on Tiller. "Yes, OK, but we know about the press. But it becomes a much more intense problem when you have a judge, confronted with evidence of criminal wrongdoing, who throws it out on some technicality because he wants to be liked at the country club. Then it's intense." Tiller, said O'Reilly on Jan. 6 of this year, was a major supporter of then-Gov. Kathleen Sebelius. "I think it's unfairly characterized as just a grip and grin relationship. He was a pretty big supporter of hers." She had cashed her campaign check from Tiller, "doesn't seem to be real upset about this guy operating a death mill, which is exactly what it is in her state, does she?" he asked on July 14 of last year. "Maybe she'll - maybe she'll pardon him," he scoffed two months ago. This is where it gets most troubling. O'Reilly's language describing Tiller, and accusing the state and its elites of complicity in his actions, could become extremely vivid. On June 12, 2007, he said, "Yes, I think we all know what this is. And if the state of Kansas doesn't stop this man, then anybody who prevents that from happening has blood on their hands as the governor does right now, Governor Sebelius." Three days later, he added, "No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands. But now so does Governor Sebelius. She is not fit to serve. Nor is any Kansas politician who supports Tiller's business of destruction. I wouldn't want to be these people if there is a Judgment Day. I just - you know...Kansas is a great state, but this is a disgrace upon everyone who lives in Kansas. Is it not?" This characterization of Tiller fits exactly into ancient conservative, paranoid stories: a decadent, permissive and callous elite tolerates moral monstrosities that every common-sense citizen just knows to be awful. Conspiring against our folk wisdom, O'Reilly says, the sophisticates have shielded Tiller from the appropriate, legal consequences for his deeds. It's left to "judgment day" to give him what's coming. O'Reilly didn't tell anyone to do anything violent, but he did put Tiller in the public eye, and help make him the focus of a movement with a history of violence against exactly these kinds of targets (including Tiller himself, who had already been shot). In those circumstances, flinging around words like "blood on their hands," "pardon," "country club" and "judgment day" was sensationally irresponsible. Has O'Reilly been, in effect, yelling "Fire" in a crowded theater and therefore, does he have some responsibility for inciting the death of Doctor Tiller, who was murdered standing in the foyer of his church during Sunday religious services, by an anti-abortion terrorist? Or was it just the act of a terrorist, and O'Reilly's continual attacks on the doctor ("No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands") had no connection with his murder?

content: "http://blog.beliefnet.com/stevenwaldman/2009/05/tiller-assassination.html" quote: ...at a minimum, conservatives have to make a new choice: take seriously right wing extremists - the real ones, not the bloviators -or run the risk of truly being lumped together. In a way, conservatives now face a choice similar to what liberals in the late 1960s and early 1970s faced during the hayday of the Weather Underground. Some on the New Left defended them as legitimate-albeit-excitable members of their broad coalition, while other more traditional liberals attacked them as extremists who violated liberal ideals. My sense of the history is that enough on the New Left defended extremists to tar all of liberalism. Will that happen for conservatives now?

content: Just to correct something here... The vast majority of late-term abortions do not occur because the child isn't wanted. Typically, they occur because of a severe deformity in the fetus or a major health problem for the mother. I used to be obsessively pro-life, and I heard all the rhetoric about late-term abortions, and I thought it was that simple. I THOUGHT that they happened because women who were stupid and waited to get the abortion (which I thought was wrong anyway), and that healthy infants were being slaughtered. And THAT sort of lie is the garbage I believed because I swallowed the right-wing religious rhetoric hook, line, and sinker. The truth is that late-term abortions only occur in extreme circumstances. Often, the babies are WANTED, and it turns out that the baby would be born with such extreme deformities (malfunctioning organs, missing heart chambers, NO BRAIN) that it would only suffer severely before dying a miserable death. Sometimes, the risk is even so bad that the fetus could die while still in the mother, leading to severe complications that put the mother's life at risk. These things HAPPEN. And there's often no way to know until LATE in the pregnancy. Go on... read a few case studies. Read it, if you dare to subject yourself to the medical truths. Other circumstances are when younger girls are raped and are not allowed to see a doctor until it becomes obvious that there's no way to hide the pregnancy. This image of perfectly healthy mothers with perfectly healthy fetuses strolling in for late-term abortions because they just decided they had a "headache" (as one poster here put it), or were depressed, or just decided they didn't want a kid... that's BULL. You see, it's easy to condemn things when you have an idealized negative view of the opponents. It's easy to condemn women and the doctors who provide the services they need when you don't know the specifics, when you can imagine that they're callous, careless people who want to kill children... which is the farthest thing from the truth.

content: O'Reilly repeatedly claimed that Dr. Tiller, or "Tiller the Killer" as he referred to him, would perform late term abortions right up to the end of the ninth month for anyone with $5,000, no questions asked. He claimed you could "murder your child" simply because you were having a bad day. That's typical O'Reilly and FOX Noise BS! A late term abortion can't legally be performed in Kansas until after at least two physicians have independently determined that not terminating the pregnancy would cause serious irreparable harm to the mother. In some cases that would include the mother's probable death. I can't imagine any pregnant woman or doctor taking such a decision lightly.

content: "http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/05/31/AR2009053101181.html?wprss=rss_politics" quote: George R. Tiller, the nation's most prominent provider of controversial late-term abortions, was shot and killed yesterday in the lobby of his Lutheran church in Wichita, where he was serving as an usher. "http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2009/05/31/tiller/index.html" quote: When his show airs tomorrow, Bill O'Reilly will most certainly decry the death of Kansas doctor George Tiller, who was killed Sunday while attending church services with his wife. Tiller, O'Reilly will say, was a man who was guilty of barbaric acts, but a civilized society does not resort to lawless murder, even against its worst members. And O'Reilly, we can assume, will genuinely mean this. But there's no other person who bears as much responsibility for the characterization of Tiller as a savage on the loose, killing babies willy-nilly thanks to the collusion of would-be sophisticated cultural elites, a bought-and-paid-for governor and scofflaw secular journalists. Tiller's name first appeared on "The Factor" on Feb. 25, 2005. Since then, O'Reilly and his guest hosts have brought up the doctor on 28 more episodes, including as recently as April 27 of this year. Almost invariably, Tiller is described as "Tiller the Baby Killer." Tiller, O'Reilly likes to say, "destroys fetuses for just about any reason right up until the birth date for $5,000." He's guilty of "Nazi stuff," said O'Reilly on June 8, 2005; a moral equivalent to NAMBLA and al-Qaida, he suggested on March 15, 2006. "This is the kind of stuff happened in Mao's China, Hitler's Germany, Stalin's Soviet Union," said O'Reilly on Nov. 9, 2006. O'Reilly has also frequently linked Tiller to his longtime obsession, child molestation and rape. Because a young teenager who received an abortion from Tiller could, by definition, have been a victim of statutory rape, O'Reilly frequently suggested that the clinic was covering up for child rapists (rather than teenage boyfriends) by refusing to release records on the abortions performed. When Kansas Attorney General Phill Kline, an O'Reilly favorite who faced harsh criticism for seeking Tiller's records, was facing electoral defeat by challenger Paul Morrison, O'Reilly said, "Now we don't endorse candidates here, but obviously, that would be a colossal mistake. Society must afford some protection for viable babies and children who are raped." (Morrison ultimately unseated Kline.) This is where O'Reilly's campaign against George Tiller becomes dangerous. While he never advocated anything violent or illegal, the Fox bully repeatedly portrayed the doctor as a murderer on the loose, allowed to do whatever he wanted by corrupt and decadent authorities. "Also, it looks like Dr. Tiller, who some call Tiller the Baby Killer, is spending a large amount of money in order to get Mr. Morrison elected. That opens up all kinds of questions," said O'Reilly on Nov. 6, 2006, in one of many suggestions that Tiller was improperly influencing the election. Tiller's excuses for performing late-term abortions, O'Reilly suggested, were frou-frou, New Age, false ailments: The woman might have a headache or anxiety, or have been dumped by her boyfriend. She might be "depressed," scoffed O'Reilly, which he dismissed as "feeling a bit blue and carrying a certified check." There was, he proposed on Jan. 5, 2007, a kind of elite conspiracy of silence on Tiller. "Yes, OK, but we know about the press. But it becomes a much more intense problem when you have a judge, confronted with evidence of criminal wrongdoing, who throws it out on some technicality because he wants to be liked at the country club. Then it's intense." Tiller, said O'Reilly on Jan. 6 of this year, was a major supporter of then-Gov. Kathleen Sebelius. "I think it's unfairly characterized as just a grip and grin relationship. He was a pretty big supporter of hers." She had cashed her campaign check from Tiller, "doesn't seem to be real upset about this guy operating a death mill, which is exactly what it is in her state, does she?" he asked on July 14 of last year. "Maybe she'll - maybe she'll pardon him," he scoffed two months ago. This is where it gets most troubling. O'Reilly's language describing Tiller, and accusing the state and its elites of complicity in his actions, could become extremely vivid. On June 12, 2007, he said, "Yes, I think we all know what this is. And if the state of Kansas doesn't stop this man, then anybody who prevents that from happening has blood on their hands as the governor does right now, Governor Sebelius." Three days later, he added, "No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands. But now so does Governor Sebelius. She is not fit to serve. Nor is any Kansas politician who supports Tiller's business of destruction. I wouldn't want to be these people if there is a Judgment Day. I just - you know...Kansas is a great state, but this is a disgrace upon everyone who lives in Kansas. Is it not?" This characterization of Tiller fits exactly into ancient conservative, paranoid stories: a decadent, permissive and callous elite tolerates moral monstrosities that every common-sense citizen just knows to be awful. Conspiring against our folk wisdom, O'Reilly says, the sophisticates have shielded Tiller from the appropriate, legal consequences for his deeds. It's left to "judgment day" to give him what's coming. O'Reilly didn't tell anyone to do anything violent, but he did put Tiller in the public eye, and help make him the focus of a movement with a history of violence against exactly these kinds of targets (including Tiller himself, who had already been shot). In those circumstances, flinging around words like "blood on their hands," "pardon," "country club" and "judgment day" was sensationally irresponsible. Has O'Reilly been, in effect, yelling "Fire" in a crowded theater and therefore, does he have some responsibility for inciting the death of Doctor Tiller, who was murdered standing in the foyer of his church during Sunday religious services, by an anti-abortion terrorist? Or was it just the act of a terrorist, and O'Reilly's continual attacks on the doctor ("No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands") had no connection with his murder?
quote: George R. Tiller, the nation's most prominent provider of controversial late-term abortions, was shot and killed yesterday in the lobby of his Lutheran church in Wichita, where he was serving as an usher.
reply: "http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/05/31/AR2009053101181.html?wprss=rss_politics"  "http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2009/05/31/tiller/index.html" quote: When his show airs tomorrow, Bill O'Reilly will most certainly decry the death of Kansas doctor George Tiller, who was killed Sunday while attending church services with his wife. Tiller, O'Reilly will say, was a man who was guilty of barbaric acts, but a civilized society does not resort to lawless murder, even against its worst members. And O'Reilly, we can assume, will genuinely mean this. But there's no other person who bears as much responsibility for the characterization of Tiller as a savage on the loose, killing babies willy-nilly thanks to the collusion of would-be sophisticated cultural elites, a bought-and-paid-for governor and scofflaw secular journalists. Tiller's name first appeared on "The Factor" on Feb. 25, 2005. Since then, O'Reilly and his guest hosts have brought up the doctor on 28 more episodes, including as recently as April 27 of this year. Almost invariably, Tiller is described as "Tiller the Baby Killer." Tiller, O'Reilly likes to say, "destroys fetuses for just about any reason right up until the birth date for $5,000." He's guilty of "Nazi stuff," said O'Reilly on June 8, 2005; a moral equivalent to NAMBLA and al-Qaida, he suggested on March 15, 2006. "This is the kind of stuff happened in Mao's China, Hitler's Germany, Stalin's Soviet Union," said O'Reilly on Nov. 9, 2006. O'Reilly has also frequently linked Tiller to his longtime obsession, child molestation and rape. Because a young teenager who received an abortion from Tiller could, by definition, have been a victim of statutory rape, O'Reilly frequently suggested that the clinic was covering up for child rapists (rather than teenage boyfriends) by refusing to release records on the abortions performed. When Kansas Attorney General Phill Kline, an O'Reilly favorite who faced harsh criticism for seeking Tiller's records, was facing electoral defeat by challenger Paul Morrison, O'Reilly said, "Now we don't endorse candidates here, but obviously, that would be a colossal mistake. Society must afford some protection for viable babies and children who are raped." (Morrison ultimately unseated Kline.) This is where O'Reilly's campaign against George Tiller becomes dangerous. While he never advocated anything violent or illegal, the Fox bully repeatedly portrayed the doctor as a murderer on the loose, allowed to do whatever he wanted by corrupt and decadent authorities. "Also, it looks like Dr. Tiller, who some call Tiller the Baby Killer, is spending a large amount of money in order to get Mr. Morrison elected. That opens up all kinds of questions," said O'Reilly on Nov. 6, 2006, in one of many suggestions that Tiller was improperly influencing the election. Tiller's excuses for performing late-term abortions, O'Reilly suggested, were frou-frou, New Age, false ailments: The woman might have a headache or anxiety, or have been dumped by her boyfriend. She might be "depressed," scoffed O'Reilly, which he dismissed as "feeling a bit blue and carrying a certified check." There was, he proposed on Jan. 5, 2007, a kind of elite conspiracy of silence on Tiller. "Yes, OK, but we know about the press. But it becomes a much more intense problem when you have a judge, confronted with evidence of criminal wrongdoing, who throws it out on some technicality because he wants to be liked at the country club. Then it's intense." Tiller, said O'Reilly on Jan. 6 of this year, was a major supporter of then-Gov. Kathleen Sebelius. "I think it's unfairly characterized as just a grip and grin relationship. He was a pretty big supporter of hers." She had cashed her campaign check from Tiller, "doesn't seem to be real upset about this guy operating a death mill, which is exactly what it is in her state, does she?" he asked on July 14 of last year. "Maybe she'll - maybe she'll pardon him," he scoffed two months ago. This is where it gets most troubling. O'Reilly's language describing Tiller, and accusing the state and its elites of complicity in his actions, could become extremely vivid. On June 12, 2007, he said, "Yes, I think we all know what this is. And if the state of Kansas doesn't stop this man, then anybody who prevents that from happening has blood on their hands as the governor does right now, Governor Sebelius." Three days later, he added, "No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands. But now so does Governor Sebelius. She is not fit to serve. Nor is any Kansas politician who supports Tiller's business of destruction. I wouldn't want to be these people if there is a Judgment Day. I just - you know...Kansas is a great state, but this is a disgrace upon everyone who lives in Kansas. Is it not?" This characterization of Tiller fits exactly into ancient conservative, paranoid stories: a decadent, permissive and callous elite tolerates moral monstrosities that every common-sense citizen just knows to be awful. Conspiring against our folk wisdom, O'Reilly says, the sophisticates have shielded Tiller from the appropriate, legal consequences for his deeds. It's left to "judgment day" to give him what's coming. O'Reilly didn't tell anyone to do anything violent, but he did put Tiller in the public eye, and help make him the focus of a movement with a history of violence against exactly these kinds of targets (including Tiller himself, who had already been shot). In those circumstances, flinging around words like "blood on their hands," "pardon," "country club" and "judgment day" was sensationally irresponsible. Has O'Reilly been, in effect, yelling "Fire" in a crowded theater and therefore, does he have some responsibility for inciting the death of Doctor Tiller, who was murdered standing in the foyer of his church during Sunday religious services, by an anti-abortion terrorist? Or was it just the act of a terrorist, and O'Reilly's continual attacks on the doctor ("No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands") had no connection with his murder?
title: Bill O'Reilly and the Kansas Terrorist: Cause and Effect?

content: Just to correct something here... The vast majority of late-term abortions do not occur because the child isn't wanted. Typically, they occur because of a severe deformity in the fetus or a major health problem for the mother. I used to be obsessively pro-life, and I heard all the rhetoric about late-term abortions, and I thought it was that simple. I THOUGHT that they happened because women who were stupid and waited to get the abortion (which I thought was wrong anyway), and that healthy infants were being slaughtered. And THAT sort of lie is the garbage I believed because I swallowed the right-wing religious rhetoric hook, line, and sinker. The truth is that late-term abortions only occur in extreme circumstances. Often, the babies are WANTED, and it turns out that the baby would be born with such extreme deformities (malfunctioning organs, missing heart chambers, NO BRAIN) that it would only suffer severely before dying a miserable death. Sometimes, the risk is even so bad that the fetus could die while still in the mother, leading to severe complications that put the mother's life at risk. These things HAPPEN. And there's often no way to know until LATE in the pregnancy. Go on... read a few case studies. Read it, if you dare to subject yourself to the medical truths. Other circumstances are when younger girls are raped and are not allowed to see a doctor until it becomes obvious that there's no way to hide the pregnancy. This image of perfectly healthy mothers with perfectly healthy fetuses strolling in for late-term abortions because they just decided they had a "headache" (as one poster here put it), or were depressed, or just decided they didn't want a kid... that's BULL. You see, it's easy to condemn things when you have an idealized negative view of the opponents. It's easy to condemn women and the doctors who provide the services they need when you don't know the specifics, when you can imagine that they're callous, careless people who want to kill children... which is the farthest thing from the truth.

content: O'Reilly repeatedly claimed that Dr. Tiller, or "Tiller the Killer" as he referred to him, would perform late term abortions right up to the end of the ninth month for anyone with $5,000, no questions asked. He claimed you could "murder your child" simply because you were having a bad day. That's typical O'Reilly and FOX Noise BS! A late term abortion can't legally be performed in Kansas until after at least two physicians have independently determined that not terminating the pregnancy would cause serious irreparable harm to the mother. In some cases that would include the mother's probable death. I can't imagine any pregnant woman or doctor taking such a decision lightly.

content: "http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/05/31/AR2009053101181.html?wprss=rss_politics" quote: George R. Tiller, the nation's most prominent provider of controversial late-term abortions, was shot and killed yesterday in the lobby of his Lutheran church in Wichita, where he was serving as an usher. "http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2009/05/31/tiller/index.html" quote: When his show airs tomorrow, Bill O'Reilly will most certainly decry the death of Kansas doctor George Tiller, who was killed Sunday while attending church services with his wife. Tiller, O'Reilly will say, was a man who was guilty of barbaric acts, but a civilized society does not resort to lawless murder, even against its worst members. And O'Reilly, we can assume, will genuinely mean this. But there's no other person who bears as much responsibility for the characterization of Tiller as a savage on the loose, killing babies willy-nilly thanks to the collusion of would-be sophisticated cultural elites, a bought-and-paid-for governor and scofflaw secular journalists. Tiller's name first appeared on "The Factor" on Feb. 25, 2005. Since then, O'Reilly and his guest hosts have brought up the doctor on 28 more episodes, including as recently as April 27 of this year. Almost invariably, Tiller is described as "Tiller the Baby Killer." Tiller, O'Reilly likes to say, "destroys fetuses for just about any reason right up until the birth date for $5,000." He's guilty of "Nazi stuff," said O'Reilly on June 8, 2005; a moral equivalent to NAMBLA and al-Qaida, he suggested on March 15, 2006. "This is the kind of stuff happened in Mao's China, Hitler's Germany, Stalin's Soviet Union," said O'Reilly on Nov. 9, 2006. O'Reilly has also frequently linked Tiller to his longtime obsession, child molestation and rape. Because a young teenager who received an abortion from Tiller could, by definition, have been a victim of statutory rape, O'Reilly frequently suggested that the clinic was covering up for child rapists (rather than teenage boyfriends) by refusing to release records on the abortions performed. When Kansas Attorney General Phill Kline, an O'Reilly favorite who faced harsh criticism for seeking Tiller's records, was facing electoral defeat by challenger Paul Morrison, O'Reilly said, "Now we don't endorse candidates here, but obviously, that would be a colossal mistake. Society must afford some protection for viable babies and children who are raped." (Morrison ultimately unseated Kline.) This is where O'Reilly's campaign against George Tiller becomes dangerous. While he never advocated anything violent or illegal, the Fox bully repeatedly portrayed the doctor as a murderer on the loose, allowed to do whatever he wanted by corrupt and decadent authorities. "Also, it looks like Dr. Tiller, who some call Tiller the Baby Killer, is spending a large amount of money in order to get Mr. Morrison elected. That opens up all kinds of questions," said O'Reilly on Nov. 6, 2006, in one of many suggestions that Tiller was improperly influencing the election. Tiller's excuses for performing late-term abortions, O'Reilly suggested, were frou-frou, New Age, false ailments: The woman might have a headache or anxiety, or have been dumped by her boyfriend. She might be "depressed," scoffed O'Reilly, which he dismissed as "feeling a bit blue and carrying a certified check." There was, he proposed on Jan. 5, 2007, a kind of elite conspiracy of silence on Tiller. "Yes, OK, but we know about the press. But it becomes a much more intense problem when you have a judge, confronted with evidence of criminal wrongdoing, who throws it out on some technicality because he wants to be liked at the country club. Then it's intense." Tiller, said O'Reilly on Jan. 6 of this year, was a major supporter of then-Gov. Kathleen Sebelius. "I think it's unfairly characterized as just a grip and grin relationship. He was a pretty big supporter of hers." She had cashed her campaign check from Tiller, "doesn't seem to be real upset about this guy operating a death mill, which is exactly what it is in her state, does she?" he asked on July 14 of last year. "Maybe she'll - maybe she'll pardon him," he scoffed two months ago. This is where it gets most troubling. O'Reilly's language describing Tiller, and accusing the state and its elites of complicity in his actions, could become extremely vivid. On June 12, 2007, he said, "Yes, I think we all know what this is. And if the state of Kansas doesn't stop this man, then anybody who prevents that from happening has blood on their hands as the governor does right now, Governor Sebelius." Three days later, he added, "No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands. But now so does Governor Sebelius. She is not fit to serve. Nor is any Kansas politician who supports Tiller's business of destruction. I wouldn't want to be these people if there is a Judgment Day. I just - you know...Kansas is a great state, but this is a disgrace upon everyone who lives in Kansas. Is it not?" This characterization of Tiller fits exactly into ancient conservative, paranoid stories: a decadent, permissive and callous elite tolerates moral monstrosities that every common-sense citizen just knows to be awful. Conspiring against our folk wisdom, O'Reilly says, the sophisticates have shielded Tiller from the appropriate, legal consequences for his deeds. It's left to "judgment day" to give him what's coming. O'Reilly didn't tell anyone to do anything violent, but he did put Tiller in the public eye, and help make him the focus of a movement with a history of violence against exactly these kinds of targets (including Tiller himself, who had already been shot). In those circumstances, flinging around words like "blood on their hands," "pardon," "country club" and "judgment day" was sensationally irresponsible. Has O'Reilly been, in effect, yelling "Fire" in a crowded theater and therefore, does he have some responsibility for inciting the death of Doctor Tiller, who was murdered standing in the foyer of his church during Sunday religious services, by an anti-abortion terrorist? Or was it just the act of a terrorist, and O'Reilly's continual attacks on the doctor ("No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands") had no connection with his murder?

content: Just to correct something here... The vast majority of late-term abortions do not occur because the child isn't wanted. Typically, they occur because of a severe deformity in the fetus or a major health problem for the mother. I used to be obsessively pro-life, and I heard all the rhetoric about late-term abortions, and I thought it was that simple. I THOUGHT that they happened because women who were stupid and waited to get the abortion (which I thought was wrong anyway), and that healthy infants were being slaughtered. And THAT sort of lie is the garbage I believed because I swallowed the right-wing religious rhetoric hook, line, and sinker. The truth is that late-term abortions only occur in extreme circumstances. Often, the babies are WANTED, and it turns out that the baby would be born with such extreme deformities (malfunctioning organs, missing heart chambers, NO BRAIN) that it would only suffer severely before dying a miserable death. Sometimes, the risk is even so bad that the fetus could die while still in the mother, leading to severe complications that put the mother's life at risk. These things HAPPEN. And there's often no way to know until LATE in the pregnancy. Go on... read a few case studies. Read it, if you dare to subject yourself to the medical truths. Other circumstances are when younger girls are raped and are not allowed to see a doctor until it becomes obvious that there's no way to hide the pregnancy. This image of perfectly healthy mothers with perfectly healthy fetuses strolling in for late-term abortions because they just decided they had a "headache" (as one poster here put it), or were depressed, or just decided they didn't want a kid... that's BULL. You see, it's easy to condemn things when you have an idealized negative view of the opponents. It's easy to condemn women and the doctors who provide the services they need when you don't know the specifics, when you can imagine that they're callous, careless people who want to kill children... which is the farthest thing from the truth.

content: O'Reilly repeatedly claimed that Dr. Tiller, or "Tiller the Killer" as he referred to him, would perform late term abortions right up to the end of the ninth month for anyone with $5,000, no questions asked. He claimed you could "murder your child" simply because you were having a bad day. That's typical O'Reilly and FOX Noise BS! A late term abortion can't legally be performed in Kansas until after at least two physicians have independently determined that not terminating the pregnancy would cause serious irreparable harm to the mother. In some cases that would include the mother's probable death. I can't imagine any pregnant woman or doctor taking such a decision lightly.

title: Bill O'Reilly and the Kansas Terrorist: Cause and Effect?

content: "http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/05/31/AR2009053101181.html?wprss=rss_politics" quote: George R. Tiller, the nation's most prominent provider of controversial late-term abortions, was shot and killed yesterday in the lobby of his Lutheran church in Wichita, where he was serving as an usher. "http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2009/05/31/tiller/index.html" quote: When his show airs tomorrow, Bill O'Reilly will most certainly decry the death of Kansas doctor George Tiller, who was killed Sunday while attending church services with his wife. Tiller, O'Reilly will say, was a man who was guilty of barbaric acts, but a civilized society does not resort to lawless murder, even against its worst members. And O'Reilly, we can assume, will genuinely mean this. But there's no other person who bears as much responsibility for the characterization of Tiller as a savage on the loose, killing babies willy-nilly thanks to the collusion of would-be sophisticated cultural elites, a bought-and-paid-for governor and scofflaw secular journalists. Tiller's name first appeared on "The Factor" on Feb. 25, 2005. Since then, O'Reilly and his guest hosts have brought up the doctor on 28 more episodes, including as recently as April 27 of this year. Almost invariably, Tiller is described as "Tiller the Baby Killer." Tiller, O'Reilly likes to say, "destroys fetuses for just about any reason right up until the birth date for $5,000." He's guilty of "Nazi stuff," said O'Reilly on June 8, 2005; a moral equivalent to NAMBLA and al-Qaida, he suggested on March 15, 2006. "This is the kind of stuff happened in Mao's China, Hitler's Germany, Stalin's Soviet Union," said O'Reilly on Nov. 9, 2006. O'Reilly has also frequently linked Tiller to his longtime obsession, child molestation and rape. Because a young teenager who received an abortion from Tiller could, by definition, have been a victim of statutory rape, O'Reilly frequently suggested that the clinic was covering up for child rapists (rather than teenage boyfriends) by refusing to release records on the abortions performed. When Kansas Attorney General Phill Kline, an O'Reilly favorite who faced harsh criticism for seeking Tiller's records, was facing electoral defeat by challenger Paul Morrison, O'Reilly said, "Now we don't endorse candidates here, but obviously, that would be a colossal mistake. Society must afford some protection for viable babies and children who are raped." (Morrison ultimately unseated Kline.) This is where O'Reilly's campaign against George Tiller becomes dangerous. While he never advocated anything violent or illegal, the Fox bully repeatedly portrayed the doctor as a murderer on the loose, allowed to do whatever he wanted by corrupt and decadent authorities. "Also, it looks like Dr. Tiller, who some call Tiller the Baby Killer, is spending a large amount of money in order to get Mr. Morrison elected. That opens up all kinds of questions," said O'Reilly on Nov. 6, 2006, in one of many suggestions that Tiller was improperly influencing the election. Tiller's excuses for performing late-term abortions, O'Reilly suggested, were frou-frou, New Age, false ailments: The woman might have a headache or anxiety, or have been dumped by her boyfriend. She might be "depressed," scoffed O'Reilly, which he dismissed as "feeling a bit blue and carrying a certified check." There was, he proposed on Jan. 5, 2007, a kind of elite conspiracy of silence on Tiller. "Yes, OK, but we know about the press. But it becomes a much more intense problem when you have a judge, confronted with evidence of criminal wrongdoing, who throws it out on some technicality because he wants to be liked at the country club. Then it's intense." Tiller, said O'Reilly on Jan. 6 of this year, was a major supporter of then-Gov. Kathleen Sebelius. "I think it's unfairly characterized as just a grip and grin relationship. He was a pretty big supporter of hers." She had cashed her campaign check from Tiller, "doesn't seem to be real upset about this guy operating a death mill, which is exactly what it is in her state, does she?" he asked on July 14 of last year. "Maybe she'll - maybe she'll pardon him," he scoffed two months ago. This is where it gets most troubling. O'Reilly's language describing Tiller, and accusing the state and its elites of complicity in his actions, could become extremely vivid. On June 12, 2007, he said, "Yes, I think we all know what this is. And if the state of Kansas doesn't stop this man, then anybody who prevents that from happening has blood on their hands as the governor does right now, Governor Sebelius." Three days later, he added, "No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands. But now so does Governor Sebelius. She is not fit to serve. Nor is any Kansas politician who supports Tiller's business of destruction. I wouldn't want to be these people if there is a Judgment Day. I just - you know...Kansas is a great state, but this is a disgrace upon everyone who lives in Kansas. Is it not?" This characterization of Tiller fits exactly into ancient conservative, paranoid stories: a decadent, permissive and callous elite tolerates moral monstrosities that every common-sense citizen just knows to be awful. Conspiring against our folk wisdom, O'Reilly says, the sophisticates have shielded Tiller from the appropriate, legal consequences for his deeds. It's left to "judgment day" to give him what's coming. O'Reilly didn't tell anyone to do anything violent, but he did put Tiller in the public eye, and help make him the focus of a movement with a history of violence against exactly these kinds of targets (including Tiller himself, who had already been shot). In those circumstances, flinging around words like "blood on their hands," "pardon," "country club" and "judgment day" was sensationally irresponsible. Has O'Reilly been, in effect, yelling "Fire" in a crowded theater and therefore, does he have some responsibility for inciting the death of Doctor Tiller, who was murdered standing in the foyer of his church during Sunday religious services, by an anti-abortion terrorist? Or was it just the act of a terrorist, and O'Reilly's continual attacks on the doctor ("No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands") had no connection with his murder?

This characterization of Tiller fits exactly into ancient conservative, paranoid stories: a decadent, permissive and callous elite tolerates moral monstrosities that every common-sense citizen just knows to be awful. Conspiring against our folk wisdom, O'Reilly says, the sophisticates have shielded Tiller from the appropriate, legal consequences for his deeds. It's left to "judgment day" to give him what's coming. O'Reilly didn't tell anyone to do anything violent, but he did put Tiller in the public eye, and help make him the focus of a movement with a history of violence against exactly these kinds of targets (including Tiller himself, who had already been shot). In those circumstances, flinging around words like "blood on their hands," "pardon," "country club" and "judgment day" was sensationally irresponsible. Has O'Reilly been, in effect, yelling "Fire" in a crowded theater and therefore, does he have some responsibility for inciting the death of Doctor Tiller, who was murdered standing in the foyer of his church during Sunday religious services, by an anti-abortion terrorist? Or was it just the act of a terrorist, and O'Reilly's continual attacks on the doctor ("No question Dr. Tiller has blood on his hands") had no connection with his murder?
title: Bill O'Reilly and the Kansas Terrorist: Cause and Effect?

content: Just to correct something here... The vast majority of late-term abortions do not occur because the child isn't wanted. Typically, they occur because of a severe deformity in the fetus or a major health problem for the mother. I used to be obsessively pro-life, and I heard all the rhetoric about late-term abortions, and I thought it was that simple. I THOUGHT that they happened because women who were stupid and waited to get the abortion (which I thought was wrong anyway), and that healthy infants were being slaughtered. And THAT sort of lie is the garbage I believed because I swallowed the right-wing religious rhetoric hook, line, and sinker. The truth is that late-term abortions only occur in extreme circumstances. Often, the babies are WANTED, and it turns out that the baby would be born with such extreme deformities (malfunctioning organs, missing heart chambers, NO BRAIN) that it would only suffer severely before dying a miserable death. Sometimes, the risk is even so bad that the fetus could die while still in the mother, leading to severe complications that put the mother's life at risk. These things HAPPEN. And there's often no way to know until LATE in the pregnancy. Go on... read a few case studies. Read it, if you dare to subject yourself to the medical truths. Other circumstances are when younger girls are raped and are not allowed to see a doctor until it becomes obvious that there's no way to hide the pregnancy. This image of perfectly healthy mothers with perfectly healthy fetuses strolling in for late-term abortions because they just decided they had a "headache" (as one poster here put it), or were depressed, or just decided they didn't want a kid... that's BULL. You see, it's easy to condemn things when you have an idealized negative view of the opponents. It's easy to condemn women and the doctors who provide the services they need when you don't know the specifics, when you can imagine that they're callous, careless people who want to kill children... which is the farthest thing from the truth.

It's easy to condemn women and the doctors who provide the services they need when you don't know the specifics, when you can imagine that they're callous, careless people who want to kill children... which is the farthest thing from the truth.
title: Bill O'Reilly and the Kansas Terrorist: Cause and Effect?

content: O'Reilly repeatedly claimed that Dr. Tiller, or "Tiller the Killer" as he referred to him, would perform late term abortions right up to the end of the ninth month for anyone with $5,000, no questions asked. He claimed you could "murder your child" simply because you were having a bad day. That's typical O'Reilly and FOX Noise BS! A late term abortion can't legally be performed in Kansas until after at least two physicians have independently determined that not terminating the pregnancy would cause serious irreparable harm to the mother. In some cases that would include the mother's probable death. I can't imagine any pregnant woman or doctor taking such a decision lightly.
